doc.ContractDescription: THE PROPOSED INVESTIGATION ADDRESSES THE ISSUE OF THE MECHANISM(S) OF CORONAL HEATING IN ACTIVE REGION LOOPS BY EXPLOITING THE NEW AND UNIQUE DIAGNOSTICS PROVIDED BY THE INTERFACE REGION IMAGING SPECTROGRAPH (IRIS). WE FOCUS ON SMALL SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL SCALE MOSS BRIGHTENINGS, WHICH OFFER A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO INVESTIGATE THE CHARACTERISTIC OF CORONAL ENERGY RELEASE, THE RESPONSE OF THE PLASMA TO VERY IMPULSIVE HEATING EVENTS, AND THE ROLE OF PARTICLE ACCELERATION IN ACTIVE REGION HEATING. THE IRIS TRANSITION REGION AND CHROMOSPHERIC OBSERVATIONS AT HIGH SPATIAL, SPECTRAL AND TEMPORAL RESOLUTION, PROVIDE UNPRECEDENTED DETAILED PLASMA DIAGNOSTICS THAT ALLOW TO DETERMINE THE FINE SPATIAL AND THERMAL STRUCTURING OF THE PLASMA AT THE BASE OF CORONAL LOOPS, AND ITS DYNAMICS THROUGH DOPPLER SHIFTS AND LINE PROFILES. THE PLASMA IN THE TRANSITION REGION AND CHROMOSPHERE OF IMPULSIVELY HEATED LOOPS IS EXTREMELY SENSITIVE TO THE PROPERTIES OF THE HEATING (E.G., TOTAL ENERGY RELEASE, DURATION OF HEAT PULSES), AND ITS DYNAMICS PROVIDE FUNDAMENTAL DIAGNOSTICS FOR THE HEATING PROCESSES (E.G., NON-THERMAL ELECTRON BEAM HEATING VS. CONDUCTION). PRELIMINARY ANALYSIS OF IRIS OBSERVATIONS OF MOSS VARIABILITY STRONGLY SUGGESTS THAT THE CHROMOSPHERIC LINES IN PARTICULAR, HAVE CRUCIAL DIAGNOSTIC POTENTIAL TO DISTINGUISH DIFFERENT HEATING MECHANISMS. THEREFORE, THE INTERPRETATION OF THESE IRIS OBSERVATIONS REQUIRES THE USE OF STATE-OF- THE-ART MODELS INCLUDING NON-LTE RADIATIVE TRANSFER FOR A PROPER TREATMENT OF THE CHROMOSPHERE. WE WILL USE THE RADYN RADIATIVE- HYDRODYNAMIC LOOP MODEL (CARLSSON&STEIN 1997, LNP, 489,159; ALLRED ET AL. 2006, APJ, 644, 484), WHICH MEETS THIS REQUIREMENT AND ALSO ALLOWS TO MODEL HEATING BY NON-THERMAL ELECTRON BEAMS. BY COMPARING DIRECTLY, IN A QUANTITATIVE FASHION, THE OBSERVATIONS WITH THE PREDICTIONS OF MODELS OF IMPULSIVELY HEATED LOOPS - BOTH WITH AND WITHOUT BEAM HEATING - WE WILL BE ABLE TO INVESTIGATE THE ROLE OF BEAM HEATING IN THE ENERGETICS OF NON-FLARING ACTIVE REGION PLASMA, AND THE CONDITIONS LEADING TO EVENTS IN WHICH BEAM HEATING OCCURS. IRIS OBSERVATIONS OF THE RAPID MOSS VARIABILITY PUT VERY TIGHT CONSTRAINTS ON THE MODELS THEREFORE PROVIDING THE OPPORTUNITY TO MAKE SIGNIFICANT PROGRESS IN UNDERSTANDING ENERGY RELEASE, MECHANISMS OF ENERGY TRANSPORT, AND DYNAMIC PLASMA PROCESSES. THE PROPOSED INVESTIGATION IS THEREFORE MAXIMIZING THE SCIENCE POTENTIAL OF IRIS, FULLY TAKING ADVANTAGE OF ITS CAPABILITIES OF SPATIAL, TEMPORAL AND SPECTRAL RESOLUTION, AND USING ITS DATA AS A UNIQUE TOOL FOR UNDERSTANDING CORONAL HEATING DESPITE OBSERVING NON-CORONAL PLASMA. OUR PROPOSED INVESTIGATION IS HIGHLY RELEVANT TO FIRST TWO QUESTIONS OF THIS IRIS GI PROGRAM, CONCERNING THE TYPES OF NON-THERMAL ENERGY DOMINATING IN THE CHROMOSPHERE AND BEYOND, AND THE FLOW OF MASS AND ENERGY FROM THE CHROMOSPHERE TO THE CORONA.

doc.ContractDescription: WE PROPOSE TO USE THE RECENTLY AVAILABLE WEALTH OF INFRARED DATA FROM SPITZER, HERSCHEL, AND WISE TO PERFORM A STUDY OF STAR FORMATION IN THE OUTER GALAXY. THERE HAVE BEEN MANY OBSERVATIONAL STUDIES OF STAR FORMATION IN REGIONS IN THE SOLAR NEIGHBORHOOD, AND MASSIVE REGIONS IN THE INNER PARTS OF THE GALAXY. HOWEVER, THE OUTER GALAXY, WHICH IS INTERMEDIATE IN METALLICITY BETWEEN THE INNER GALACTIC DISK AND THE MAGELLANIC CLOUDS, AND AT MUCH LOWER VOLUME DENSITIES, HAS NOT BEEN AS EXTENSIVELY STUDIED. THE EXTENSION OF THE SPITZER AND HERSCHEL GALACTIC SURVEYS TO THE OUTER GALAXY HAS NOW MADE THIS POSSIBLE. WE WILL USE TECHNIQUES DEVELOPED IN STUDIES OF NEARBY STAR FORMATION AND MASSIVE REGIONS SUCH AS CYGNUS X TO LOCATE YOUNG STELLAR OBJECTS IN THE OUTER GALAXY, USE MODEL FITTING TO DETERMINE THEIR PROPERTIES SUCH AS LUMINOSITY AND MASS, AND STUDY THEIR CLUSTERING PROPERTIES. COMPARING THE RESULTS TO STAR FORMATION REGIONS IN OTHER PARTS OF THE GALAXY WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION ON HOW DYNAMICAL PROCESSES CAN AFFECT THE MECHANISMS THAT INFLUENCE THE FRAGMENTATION OF MOLECULAR CLOUDS AND STAR FORMATION EFFICIENCY. THE RESULTS WILL HAVE APPLICATIONS TO THE STUDY OF STAR FORMATION IN OTHER GALAXIES, WHERE GLOBAL PROPERTIES CAN BE OBSERVED BUT WE CANNOT RESOLVE INDIVIDUAL CLUSTERS OR STARS IN THE INFRARED. THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE A DATABASE OF OUTER GALAXY STAR FORMATION WHICH CAN BE USED TO SELECT OBJECTS TO FOLLOW UP WITH JWST.
doc.MajorAgency: STAR FORMATION IN THE OUTER GALAXY
doc.MajorFundingAgency: STAR FORMATION IN THE OUTER GALAXY

doc.ContractDescription: VALIDATION AND APPLICATION OF OCO-2 DATA IN THE NORTHEASTERN UNITED STATES URBAN AREAS REPRESENT A KEY TARGET FOR OCO-2 SCIENCE. WE PROPOSE TO VALIDATE OCO-2 DATA, WITH PARTICULAR FOCUS ON THE URBAN-RURAL GRADIENTS OF XCO2 IN THE NORTHEASTERN US, AND TO DEVELOP AND DEMONSTRATE METHODS FOR DETERMINING URBAN CO2 EMISSIONS USING OCO-2 DATA. ANALYZING OCO-2 DATA IN AN URBAN DOMAIN IS CHALLENGING, ESPECIALLY FOR CITIES CONTAINING, AND SURROUNDED BY, SIGNIFICANT VEGETATION. THE ENHANCEMENT OF XCO2 IN THE "URBAN DOME" IS 2-10 PPM, AND EVEN IN DENSELY POPULATED REGIONS, THE DAILY EXCHANGE OF CO2 FROM VEGETATION EQUALS OR EXCEEDS FOSSIL FUEL EMISSIONS. THE NORTHEAST US, A HEAVILY VEGETATED, DENSELY POPULATED URBAN-RURAL DOMAIN WITH A UNIQUE, COMPREHENSIVE CO2 OBSERVATION NETWORK, OFFERS A SCIENTIFICALLY AND LOGISTICALLY COMPELLING LOCUS FOR VALIDATION OF OCO-2 DATA AND FOR DEVELOPING INVERSE MODELING FRAMEWORKS TO USE OCO-2 FOR DETERMINING URBAN EMISSIONS IN LESS DATA-RICH ENVIRONMENTS AROUND THE GLOBE. THE VEGETATED LANDSCAPE OF THE NORTHEAST US IS MORE HETEROGENEOUS, WITH LOWER REFLECTIVITY, AND HAS A MORE ACTIVE BIOSPHERE WITH MUCH GREATER INFLUENCE ON CO2 FLUXES, THAN IN LOS ANGELES, THE OTHER MAJOR SITE FOR URBAN VALIDATION OF XCO2 FROM OCO-2. HAVING A VALIDATION REGION IN THE NORTHEASTERN US TARGETS ESSENTIAL CHALLENGES FOR INVERSE MODELING OF URBAN EMISSIONS USING OCO-2 SATELLITE DATA. OUR PROPOSED WORK WILL PROVIDE TO THE OCO-2 INSTRUMENT TEAM DIRECT ASSESSMENT OF THE XCO2 GRADIENTS ACROSS THE URBAN DOMAIN,TRACEABLE TO WMO STANDARDS, USING SURFACE MEASUREMENTS, TOTAL COLUMN MEASUREMENTS OF XCO2 USING TWO BRUKER EM27SUN FTIR SYSTEMS AT SEVERAL SITES, DATA FROM TWO PANDORA UV-VIS SPECTROMETERS, AND LIDAR DATA. ALL OF OUR GROUND-BASED SENSORS ARE COMPACT AND MOBILE, WHICH PROVIDES SPATIAL FLEXIBILITY FOR THE VALIDATION. PROJECT DELIVERABLES INCLUDE (1) ASSESSMENT AND VALIDATION OF THE CAPABILITY FOR OCO-2 TO ACCURATELY RESOLVE REGIONAL SCALE GRADIENTS OF XCO2 IN A MAJOR URBAN DOMAIN USING OUR NETWORK OF SOLARTRACKING FTSS AND LIDARS, INCLUDING RESULTS FROM TEMPORARY DEPLOYMENTS DIRECTLY ON OCO-2 TRACKS; (2) BASIC DATA FOR REFINEMENT OF AEROSOL CORRECTIONS FOR OCO-2 MEASUREMENTS VIA VERTICAL PROFILES OF AEROSOLS BY LIDARS AND TOTAL AEROSOL OPTICAL DEPTH MEASURED BY THE PANDORA UV-VIS SPECTROMETER; (3) ACCURATE REGIONAL CO2 EMISSIONS ESTIMATES BY COMBINING GROUND-BASED SURFACE AND COLUMN DATA WITH OCO-2 XCO2 DATA IN A DATA-MODEL INVERSION FRAMEWORK; (4) IMPROVED CHARACTERIZATION OF URBAN VEGETATION COVER AND ACTIVITY AS NEEDED FOR OCO-2 VALIDATION AND FOR THE TOTAL URBAN CARBON BUDGET; THIS WORK INCLUDES USE OF HIGHLY SELECTIVE OCO-2 FLUORESCENCE DATA; AND (5) DEVELOPMENT OF A GENERALIZED FRAMEWORK TO DERIVE URBAN/REGIONAL SCALE EMISSIONS FROM CITIES AND ASSESS THE CAPABILITY OF OCO-2 DATA ALONE TO QUANTIFY CO2 EMISSIONS IN DATA-POOR REGIONS. TAKEN AS A WHOLE, OUR PROPOSED VALIDATION AND DEVELOPMENT OF A MODEL-DATA INVERSION FRAMEWORK WILL PROVIDE A COMPREHENSIVE BASIS FOR QUANTIFYING URBAN EMISSIONS, FILLING MAJOR GAPS IN EXISTING URBAN VALIDATION EFFORTS FOR OCO-2 AND PROVIDING CRITICAL NEW INSIGHTS FOR A REGION THAT INCLUDES SIGNIFICANT BIOGENIC AND ANTHROPOGENIC CONTRIBUTIONS.

doc.ProductorServiceCode: D309: IT AND TELECOM- INFORMATION AND DATA BROADCASTING OR DATA DISTRIBUTION

doc.ContractDescription: 4535950375!DELL POWER EDGE SERVER R930 PE R930 SERV

THE INNER GALAXY (IG) THAT IS THE GALACTIC BAR REGION (GBR) AND THE CENTRAL MOLECULAR ZONE (CMZ) INCLUDING THE GALACTIC CENTER (GC) ARE, DESPITE BEING THE SITES OF DRAMATIC PROCESSES AND UNIQUE SOURCES, STILL ONLY INCOMPLETELY UNDERSTOOD. DETAILED NEW DATASETS FROM THE HERSCHEL SPACE OBSERVATORY CAN BE SYSTEMATICALLY COMBINED WITH OLDER ARCHIVAL MATERIAL TO ENABLE A NEW AND MORE COMPLETE ANALYSIS OF THE REGION, ITS LARGE-SCALE DYNAMICS, ITS UNUSUAL GIANT MOLECULAR CLOUDS, AND THE LIKELY INFLUENCES OF ITS BAR AND ITS SUPERMASSIVE BLACK HOLE. SUCH A STUDY IS BOTH TIMELY AND IMPORTANT: THE REGION HAS AFFECTED THE STRUCTURE AND EVOLUTION OF THE GALAXY; ITS INDIVIDUAL SOURCES ARE OPPORTUNITIES TO EXAMINE STAR FORMATION (FOR EXAMPLE) UNDER EXTREME CONDITIONS; THE PROCESSES FEEDING THE CMZ AND, SUBSEQUENTLY, ITS BLACK HOLE ARE IMPORTANT; AND NOT LEAST, IT IS A NEARBY TEMPLATE FOR THE INNER REGIONS OF OTHER GALAXIES. THE HERSCHEL SPACE OBSERVATORY HAS PROVIDED US WITH EXCITING NEW DATASETS INCLUDING FULL FIR PHOTOMETRIC MAPS AND HIGH- AND LOW RESOLUTION FAR-INFRARED/SUBMILLIMETER SPECTRA OF KEY SOURCES AND LINES OF THE LOCATIONS OF DYNAMICAL IMPORTANCE. ALL THESE DATASETS ARE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE FROM THE HERSCHEL SCIENCE ARCHIVE. OUR EXPERIENCED TEAM HAS ALREADY DEVELOPED PRELIMINARY MODELS, AND WE PROPOSE A THOROUGH INVESTIGATION TO COMBINE THE HERSCHEL DATASETS WITH SPITZER AND WISE DATASETS. WE WILL SUPPLEMENT THEM WITH GROUND-BASED OBSERVATIONS IN CASES WHEN IT WILL IMPROVE THE RESULTS. WE WILL THEN ANALYZE THE DATA AND USE THE RESULTS TO REFINE THE MODELS AND IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THIS KEY REGION. OUR SPECIFIC GOAL IS TO CHARACTERIZE AND MODEL THE 3 GIANT HIGH-VELOCITY MOLECULAR CLOUD CLUMPS IN THE GALAXY BAR REGION (GBR) IN DETAIL AND TO COMBINE THE CONCLUSIONS TO PRODUCE AN IMPROVED MODEL OF THE IG. WE HAVE SEVEN TASKS: (1) IDENTIFY ALL SMALLER SCALE GAS AND DUST CORES USING ARCHIVAL HERSCHEL FIR PHOTOMETRIC OBSERVATIONS AND OBTAIN THEIR PHYSICAL CHARACTERISTICS; (2) COMBINE THE CONTINUUM RESULTS WITH MOLECULAR LINE MEASUREMENTS TO ESTABLISH THE RELATIVE LOCATIONS AND MOTIONS OF THE CORES WITH RESPECT TO THE X1- AND X2-ORBITS AROUND THE GC, THE CURRENT MODEL FOR GBR/CMZ DYNAMICS; (3) SEARCH IN ALL CORES FOR OUTFLOW ACTIVITY AS SIGNS OF STAR FORMATION (SF); (4) INVESTIGATE THE SYSTEMIC AND/OR TURBULENT MOTIONS WITHIN EACH OF THE INDIVIDUAL CLUMP CORES AND WITHIN THE CLUMPS AND THEIR RELATIONSHIP TO SF; (5) COMPARE THE RESULTS TO OTHER EXTREME GAS AND DUST CLOUDS IN THE CMZ THAT SHOW LITTLE OR NO SF AND DETERMINE A POTENTIALLY ELEVATED DENSITY THRESHOLD FOR SF; (6) DETERMINE THE GAS AND DUST FLOW TOWARDS THE CMZ TO EVALUATE POSSIBLE EPISODICAL SF IN THE CMZ; AND (7) APPLY THE RESULTS TO IMPROVE THE GLOBAL DYNAMICS MODELS OF THE INTERACTION OF THE IG SOURCES WITH THE NUCLEAR POTENTIAL. THE EXTENSIVE NEW HERSCHEL PHOTOMETRIC AND SPECTROSCOPIC DATASETS, COMBINED WITH OUR ANCILLARY DATA, NOW PERMIT SUCH AN EFFORT. OUR TEAM HAS PIONEERED MANY OF THE STUDIES OF THE IG CLUMPS, AND IS EXPERT AT HERSCHEL DATA REDUCTION AND ANALYSIS.

doc.ProductorServiceCode: AD93: R&D- DEFENSE OTHER: OTHER (ADVANCED DEVELOPMENT)

doc.ContractDescription: TURBO-ELECTRIC AND HYBRID ELECTRIC DISTRIBUTED PROPULSION (TEDP) SYSTEMS HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO GREATLY REDUCE NOISE, EMISSIONS, AND FUEL BURN FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS OF AIRCRAFT. THE TEDP ARCHITECTURE USES A COMBINATION OF TURBO-ELECTRIC GENERATORS AND STORAGE ELEMENTS TO GENERATE AND DISTRIBUTE ELECTRICAL POWER TO THE MOTOR AND FAN ASSEMBLIES, WHICH PRODUCE PROPULSION. HOWEVER, SIMILAR TO TERRESTRIAL POWER SYSTEMS, TEDP WILL BE SUSCEPTIBLE TO DESTABILIZATION FROM SUDDEN POWER DISTURBANCES. ADVANCED CONTROL METHODS ARE NEEDED TO STABILIZE THE PROPULSION POWER SYSTEM. RECENT RESEARCH INTO CONTROL OF MECHANICAL AND ELECTRICAL SYSTEMS SUGGESTS THAT CONTROLLING THE SYSTEM IN TERMS OF ITS ENERGY, RATHER THAN THE CLASSICAL APPROACH OF CONTROLLING FORCES, VOLTAGES, AND CURRENTS, IS MORE EFFECTIVE AT PROTECTING AGAINST LARGE, SUDDEN DISTURBANCES. THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON EXTENDING PREVIOUS NONLINEAR CONTROL METHODS TO THE PROPULSION SYSTEMS. SPECIFICALLY, THE TEDP SYSTEM WILL BE MODELED IN TERMS OF ITS HAMILTONIAN DYNAMICS, WHICH MODEL ENERGY, AND CONTROLLED USING PASSIVITY-BASED AND ENERGY SHAPING FUNCTIONS. THEORY WILL BE DEVELOPED TO GUARANTEE STABILITY, AND RIGOROUS SIMULATION AND TESTING WILL VERIFY IT. THIS TECHNIQUE WILL ALLOW AIRCRAFT USING TEDP ARCHITECTURE TO OPERATE SAFELY, AND IT MAY BE OF USE TO ANY OTHER FUTURE SYSTEMS THAT USE TEDP.
doc.MajorAgency: ADVANCED MODELING AND CONTROL FOR TURBO-ELECTRIC A
doc.MajorFundingAgency: ADVANCED MODELING AND CONTROL FOR TURBO-ELECTRIC A

doc.ProductorServiceCode: 2840: GAS TURBINES AND JET ENGINES, AIRCRAFT, PRIME MOVING; AND COMPONENTS

doc.ContractDescription: IGF::OT::IGF VISN 1 LEGIONELLA TESTING AND WATER MANAGEMENT PLAN

A HIGH RESOLUTION GLOBAL ANALYSIS OF OCEAN SURFACE VECTOR WINDS WAS DEVELOPED BY THE OBJECTIVELY ANALYZED AIR SEA FLUXES OAFLUX PROJECT LED BY THE PI. THE ANALYSIS COVERS THE ENTIRE SATELLITE WIND OBSERVING PERIOD JULY 1987 TO THE PRESENT AND IS A SYNERGY OF 12 SATELLITE SENSORS, INCLUDING 2 SCATTEROMETERS QUIKSCAT AND ASCAT, AND 10 PASSIVE MICROWAVE RADIOMETERS AMSRE, 6 SSMI SENSORS, 2 SSMIS SENSORS, WINDSAT ONLY WIND SPEED RETRIEVALS WERE USED. HOWEVER, ONE INTRIGUING ISSUE HAS ARISEN DURING THE DEVELOPMENT, THAT IS, OAFLUX DIFFERS CONSIDERABLY FROM QUIKSCAT IN THE WIND STRESS CURL PATTERN ASSOCIATED WITH THE GULF STREAM FRONTS, ALTHOUGH OAFLUX INCLUDES QUIKSCAT IN THE SYNTHESIS. OUR QUEST FOR AN ANSWER HAS LED TO A SURPRISED FINDING. ELIMINATION OF RAIN CONTAMINATED WIND VECTOR CELLS WVCS IN QUIKSCAT APPEARS TO HAVE A BIAS EFFECT NOT ONLY ON QUIKSCAT WIND STRESS DERIVATIVE FIELDS AT OCEAN FRONTS, BUT ALSO ON THE DECADAL TENDENCY OF THE QUIKSCAT 10YEAR TIME SERIES. OSCAT IS AFFECTED IN A SIMILAR WAY AT OCEAN FRONTS. THE SOURCE OF THE RAIN BIAS IS THE SYNOPTIC WEATHER SYSTEMS IN THE MID LATITUDE STORM TRACK REGIONS AND THE TROPICAL RAIN BELTS OF THE ITCZ AND SPCZ. AS THE WVCS AFFECTED BY RAIN ARE ASSOCIATED WITH CYCLONIC WIND STRESS CURLS, THE FREQUENT OCCURRENCE OF RAIN AT THESE PREFERRED REGIONS CAUSES A PERSISTENT REMOVAL OF CYCLONIC CURLS. ELIMINATION OF RAIN FLAGGED WIND RETRIEVALS IS DEEMED AS A PREREQUISITE FOR SUCCESSFUL APPLICATIONS OF THE KUBAND SCATTEROMETER WINDS. THE QUESTIONS WE HAVE ARE WHETHER THE INCLUSION OF RAIN FLAGGED WVCS IN KUBAND SCATTEROMETERS WILL HAVE MORE BENEFITS THAN WE KNOW COULD RAIN CONTAMINATED WVCS IN KUBAND SCATTEROMETERS BE IMPROVED THROUGH CROSS VALIDATION WITH SENSORS OPERATING AT LOWER FREQUENCIES HOW CAN WE EVALUATE THE VARIOUS MULTI SENSOR VECTOR WIND PRODUCTS, WHICH USE DIFFERENT MEANS TO RECOVER THE RAIN CONTAMINATED WVCS MISSING DATA BUT THE DIFFERENCES IN THE MEANS AFFECT THE WIND ESTIMATES ON SYNOPTIC AND MESOSCALES AND ON LOW FREQUENCY DECADAL AND LONGER TIMESCALE VARIATIONS THESE QUESTIONS HAVE NO STRAIGHTFORWARD ANSWERS, AS THEY REQUIRE COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS AMONG SATELLITE DATA RECORD DEVELOPERS, RESEARCHERS WHO USE SATELLITE DERIVED WIND PRODUCTS, AND ALGORITHM DEVELOPERS WHO WORK ON RAIN ALGORITHM REFINEMENT. ON THE INDIVIDUAL LEVEL, WE PROPOSE THE FOLLOWING FIVE SPECIFIC RESEARCH FOCI AS OUR CONTRIBUTION TO IMPROVING THE KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF THESE QUESTIONS. THREE RESEARCH FOCI ARE TO ADDRESS TECHNICAL CHALLENGES I GLOBAL CHARACTERIZATION OF THE EFFECT OF RAIN BIAS IN KUBAND SCATTEROMETERS, II ENHANCEMENT OF OAFLUX TIME SERIES BY INCLUDING OSCAT AND ASCATB AND IMPROVING THE ESTIMATION AND UNCERTAINTY ANALYSIS OF NEAR SURFACE WINDS ASSOCIATED WITH SYNOPTIC STORMS, AND III IDENTIFICATION OF THE STRENGTHS AND WEAKNESSES IN OAFLUX, SCATTEROMETERS, AND OTHER SATELLITE BASED PRODUCTS IN REGIONAL AND GLOBAL APPLICATIONS. MEANWHILE, TWO RESEARCH FOCI ARE PROPOSED TO ADDRESS THE TECHNICAL CHALLENGES THROUGH SCIENTIFIC APPLICATIONS IV INVESTIGATION OF THE POTENTIAL SHIFT OF THE MEAN ITCZ LATITUDE POSITION AND ITS RELATION TO THE STRENGTHENING OF THE TROPICAL TRADE WIND SYSTEM, AND V INVESTIGATION OF THE COLLOCATION OF THE ANTARCTIC CIRCUMPOLAR CURRENT ACC FRONTS AND THE ZERO LINE OF WIND STRESS CURL AT MAJOR TOPOGRAPHIC OBSTRUCTIONS IS IT TOPOGRAPHIC CONTROLLED COUPLING OR A MANIFESTATION OF SURFACE CURRENTS ON SATELLITE WIND RETRIEVALS CLIMATE RESEARCH DEMANDS MORE THAN EVER A CLIMATE RECORD OF OCEAN SURFACE VECTOR WINDS TO ADDRESS PRESSING LONG TERM CHANGES IN THE ATMOSPHERE OCEAN SYSTEM. THE EXPECTED SIGNIFICANCE OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS IN THE POTENTIAL TO RECTIFY AND IMPROVE THE RAIN BIAS EFFECT ON THE MULTI SENSOR SYNTHESIS AND TO ADVANCE TOWARD A HIGH QUALITY OCEAN VECTOR WIND CLIMATE RECORD WITH ACCURACY AND FIDELITY THAT MEET THE NEEDS FOR CLIMATE DETECTION AND ATTRIBUTION.
doc.MajorAgency: A CONTINUOUS OCEAN VECTOR WIND ANALYSIS BASED ON S

doc.ProductorServiceCode: 6515: MEDICAL AND SURGICAL INSTRUMENTS, EQUIPMENT, AND SUPPLIES

doc.ContractDescription: THE LONG-TERM GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OBSERVE AND IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF WIND FORCING AND SEA-SURFACE HEIGHT VARIABILITY AT HIGH FREQUENCIES (PERIODS OF 1-20 DAYS) IN THE TROPICAL OCEANS. THIS PERIOD BAND IS OF INTEREST BECAUSE THE SPACE-TIME SCALES OF OCEANIC EQUATORIAL WAVES AT THESE FREQUENCIES HAVE HISTORICALLY MADE ADEQUATE OBSERVATION OF THE VARIABILITY DIFFICULT: THESE WAVES HAVE ZONAL SCALES THAT ARE VERY LARGE (EXCEEDING 3000 KM) AND MERIDIONAL SCALES THAT ARE RELATIVELY SHORT (~100 KM), MAKING ADEQUATE IN SITU MEASUREMENTS TOO COSTLY, AND THE SHORT TEMPORAL SCALES POSE CHALLENGES FOR OBSERVATION WITH SATELLITE ALTIMETERS BECAUSE THE WAVE PERIODS ARE SHORT COMPARED TO ORBIT REPEAT PERIODS. AS A RESULT, THERE HAS BEEN RELATIVELY LITTLE PROGRESS SINCE THE EARLY 1980S IN OBSERVING AND UNDERSTANDING EQUATORIAL INERTIA-GRAVITY AND MIXED ROSSBY-GRAVITY WAVES AND THEIR RESPONSE TO WIND FORCING. HOWEVER, WITH CAREFUL CONSIDERATION OF THE SATELLITE SAMPLING, IT IS POSSIBLE TO EXPLOIT THE LONG ZONAL LENGTH SCALES OF THESE HIGHFREQUENCY EQUATORIAL WAVES IN AN ANALYSIS OF SATELLITE SCATTEROMETER AND ALTIMETER DATA, OPENING UP NEW OPPORTUNITIES TO LEARN ABOUT THE PROPERTIES AND DYNAMICS OF THESE WAVES. THIS WORK SEEKS TO EXTEND THE INVESTIGATORS PREVIOUS WORK DONE ESTIMATING AND INTERPRETING THE WAVENUMBER-FREQUENCY SPECTRAL PROPERTIES OF THE OCEANIC EQUATORIAL WAVES AND THE WIND FORCING THAT DRIVES THEM. ONE GOAL IS TO EXTEND ANALYSIS OF OCEANIC EQUATORIAL WAVES IN THE 4-20-DAY PERIOD BAND FROM THE SPECTRAL DOMAIN INTO THE TIME-SPACE DOMAIN TO ADDRESS QUESTIONS ON THE SPACE-TIME VARIABILITY OF THE WAVES AND THEIR FORCING. A SECOND GOAL IS TO EXTEND WORK DONE IN ANALYZING THE RESOLUTION CAPABILITY OF THE SATELLITE SCATTEROMETER SAMPLING, AND THE ERRORS RESULTING FROM POORLY RESOLVED BUT ENERGETIC VARIABILITY, TO QUANTITATIVELY EXAMINE THE RELATIVE MERITS OF DIFFERENT APPROACHES TO ESTIMATING THE LARGE-SCALE DIURNAL WIND SIGNAL FROM COMBINATIONS OF RECENTLY INITIATED SCATTEROMETER MISSIONS. WE WILL ALSO WORK TO QUANTIFY THE REDUCTION IN ALIASING AND SAMPLING ERRORS IN GRIDDED WIND PRODUCTS THAT RESULT FROM BETTER RESOLUTION OF THE DIURNAL WIND SIGNAL. THE PROPOSED WORK WOULD USE SATELLITE SCATTER METER AND ALTIMETER DATA IN A NOVEL WAY TO ALLOW NEW INSIGHT INTO THE PROPERTIES AND DYNAMICS OF WIND AND SEA-SURFACE HEIGHT VARIABILITY AT HIGH FREQUENCIES (PERIODS OF 1-20 DAYS), A PERIOD BAND THAT HAS NOT PREVIOUSLY BEEN WELL OBSERVED BY THESE SATELLITE INSTRUMENTS.
doc.MajorAgency: HIGH-FREQUENCY WIND AND SEA SURFACE HEIGHT VARIABI
doc.MajorFundingAgency: HIGH-FREQUENCY WIND AND SEA SURFACE HEIGHT VARIABI

doc.ContractDescription: EP-W-11-003 - NATURAL RESOURCES PROTECTION MOD 0089: THE PURPOSE OF THIS MODIFICATION IS TO OBLIGATE INCREMENTAL FUNDING TO BRIDGE CONTRACT 2. MOD 0088: THE PURPOSE OF THIS MODIFICATION IS TO: (1) OBLIGATE FUNDING TO BRIDGE CONTRACT 1 AND BRIDGE CONTRACT 2; AND (2) ADJUST FUNDING TOTALS IN BRIDGE CONTRACT 2. MOD 0087: THE PURPOSE OF THIS MODIFICATION IS TO SHIFT $20,000.00 IN FUNDING FROM BRIDGE CONTRACT 1 TO BRIDGE CONTRACT 2. MOD 0086: THE PURPOSE OF THIS MODIFICATION IS TO: EXECUTE A FIVE (5) MONTH BRIDGE CONTRACT EXTENSION TO EP-W-11-003, WHICH INCORPORATES THE CONTRACTOR'S PROPOSAL AND COST ESTIMATE DATED 10 AUGUST 2016; EXTEND THE CONTRACT PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE END DATE FROM 10 SEPTEMBER 2016 TO 10 FEBRUARY 2017; ADD NEW LINE ITEM 0044 WITH THE FOLLOWING CEILING AMOUNTS, ESTIMATED COST CEILING $1,279,967.00, FIXED FEE CEILING $102,397.00, AND LEVEL OF EFFORT CEILING 10,260 HOURS; AND OBLIGATE INCREMENTAL FUNDING TO LINE ITEM 0044 TOTALING $93,000.00. MOD 0085: THE PURPOSE OF THIS MODIFICATION IS TO OBLIGATE INCREMENTAL FUNDING TO THE BRIDGE CONTRACT PERIOD. MOD 0084: THE PURPOSE OF THIS MODIFICATION IS TO : (1) DEOBLIGATE FUNDING FROM OPTION PERIOD IV TO ACCOUNT FOR SCOPE REDUCTIONS TO WORK UNDER WORK ASSIGNMENT 4-111 AND 4-115; AND (2) OBLIGATE INCREMENTAL TO THE BRIDGE CONTRACT PERIOD. MOD 0083: THE PURPOSE OF THIS MODIFICATION IS TO: (1) OBLIGATE INCREMENTAL FUNDING TO THE BRIDGE CONTRACT PERIOD/LINE ITEM 0043; (2) DEOBLIGATE FUNDING FROM OPTION PERIOD IV/LINE ITEM 0041 AND THE BRIDGE CONTRACT PERIOD/LINE ITEM 0043 FOR WORK THAT HAS BEEN STOPPED. MOD 0082: THIS BILATERAL MODIFICATION IS BEING ISSUED TO INCORPORATE INTO CONTRACT EP-W-11-003 THE TERMS OF THE CONFIDENTIAL SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT CONSISTING OF EIGHT (8) TYPED PAGES, WHICH WAS ENTERED INTO BY ABT ASSOCIATES INC, BY AND THROUGH ITS VICE PRESIDENT AND GENERAL COUNSEL, BRIAN ROEMER, AND THE UNITED STATES ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY, BY AND THROUGH ITS CONTRACTING OFFICERS SHEILA FAGAN, NATALIA FISHER-JACKSON, STEFAN MARTIYAN, GENINE MCELROY, CHRISTINE EDWARDS, AND NOELLE MILLS, EFFECTIVE (ENTER THE DATE OF THE LAST SIGNATURE ON THE SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT), AS SET FORTH ON PAGES 3 THROUGH 10 OF THIS MODIFICATION. PRIOR YEAR FUNDS BEING OBLIGATED TO FUND THE CONFIDENTIAL SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT WILL BE PAID FROM THE FOLLOWING ACCOUNTING LINE FROM OPTION PERIOD IV OF THE CONTRACT: 14-15-B-40DF-201B53X28-2505-1440SRE065-001 MOD 0081: THE PURPOSE OF THIS MODIFICATION IS TO EXECUTE A SIX (6) MONTH BRIDGE CONTRACT EXTENSION AND TO INCREASE THE OPTION PERIOD IV ESTIMATED COST CEILING BY $1,850,043.00 AND THE FIXED FEE CEILING BY $148,003.00. ADDITIONALLY, INCREMENTAL FUNDING IS OBLIGATED TO THE CONTRACT TOTALING $763,180.89 AND ADD THE FEDCONNECT CLAUSE.

doc.ContractDescription: SUBSCRIPTION FOR INTEGRATED DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSIS AND TREATMENT DATABASE FOR VISN 2 FACILITIES. IGF::CL::IGF

MERGERS AND INTERACTIONS HAVE PROFOUND EFFECTS ON THE EVOLUTION OF GALAXIES AND ON THE VARIOUS PHYSICAL PROCESSES ASSOCIATED WITH STAR FORMATION AND THE FUELING OF ACTIVE NUCLEI (AGN). THERE REMAINS, HOWEVER, AN INCOMPLETE UNDERSTANDING OF HOW INTERACTIONS AFFECT SUCH PROCESSES OR HOW IMPORTANT THEY ARE IN CONTROLLING THE APPEARANCE OF TODAY'S UNIVERSE. WE PROPOSE TO STUDY 180 INTERACTING GALAXIES IN 101 SYSTEMS SPANNING EARLY TO LATE STAGE MERGERS FOR WHICH NEWLY ARCHIVED NASA DATA ENABLE DETAILED ANALYSES OF THEIR ULTRAVIOLET-TO-FAR INFRARED (UV-FIR) SPECTRAL ENERGY DISTRIBUTIONS (SEDS). OUR GOAL IS AN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF HOW A WIDE RANGE OF KEY GALAXY PARAMETERS VARY ACROSS THE INTERACTION SEQUENCE. OUR DERIVED PHYSICAL PARAMETERS WILL INCLUDE THE TOTAL OPTICALINFRARED LUMINOSITY, STAR FORMATION RATE, SPECIFIC STAR FORMATION RATE, STELLAR MASS, DUST TEMPERATURES AND DUST MASSES, COMPACTNESS, PHOTO-DISSOCIATION REGION (PDR) FRACTIONS, AND AGN CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE FIR SED. OUR SAMPLE IS TAKEN FROM THE KEEL-KENNICUTT CATALOG OF MERGING GALAXIES (BASED ONLY ON APPARENT GALAXY SEPARATIONS AND HENCE FREE OF MORPHOLOGICAL BIAS) AND THE SURACE IRAS SAMPLE OF BRIGHT MERGERS. OUR SAMPLE CONTAINS VIRTUALLY ALL BRIGHT MERGERS WITH UV-FIR DATA IN THE ARCHIVES, INCLUDING (BUT NOT LIMITED TO) DATA FROM MISSIONS GALEX, SWIFT, SPITZER, WISE, AND HERSCHEL. WE WILL RE-REDUCE, RECALIBRATE, AND EXTRACT THE PHOTOMETRY IN UP TO 23 WAVELENGTH BANDS FROM THE UV TO THE FIR. OUR ANALYSIS PLAN EMPHASIZES THREE NEW SED MODELING TOOLS, ONE OF WHICH WE HAVE RECENTLY DEVELOPED. NEARLY ALL OF THE SOURCES ALSO HAVE SPITZER IRS SPECTRAL DATA (PRIMARILY OF THE CIRCUMNUCLEAR REGIONS), AND WE WILL USE THE IRS DATA TO SUPPLEMENT THE SED CONCLUSIONS VIA OUR OWN ALGORITHM WHICH ALSO INFERS METALLICITY, INTERSTELLAR MEDIUM (ISM) AMBIENT PRESSURE, AND EMBEDDED YOUNG STAR FRACTIONS. FINALLY, WE WILL COMPARE EACH MERGER TO THE SIMULATED PHOTOMETRY/ MORPHOLOGY OF A SUITE OF SIMULATIONS BASED ON HERNQUIST ET AL. MODELS. SEDS FOR THE SIMULATIONS WILL BE CALCULATED IN EACH CASE USING THE SUNRISE RADIATIVE TRANSFER CODE. WE WILL IDENTIFY THE SIMULATION AND INTERACTING STAGE/AGE THAT BEST REPRODUCES EACH OBSERVED MERGER'S PROPERTIES. THE RESULTS WILL ALLOW US TO REFINE AND TEST HOW PHYSICAL PARAMETERS DEVELOP IN MERGERS OF VARIOUS KINDS, AS WELL AS HELP TEST THE RELIABILITY OF THE SIMULATION ASSUMPTIONS. WE WILL IN ADDITION ANALYZE 25 NON-INTERACTING GALAXIES AS COMPARISONS. WE HAVE ALREADY SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED THE ANALYSES SUITE ON A SUBSET OF 31 GALAXIES IN 14 MERGER GROUPS. THIS INITIAL SET CONTAINED ALL THE KEEL-KENNICUTT MERGERS FOR WHICH SUITABLE HERSCHEL DATA WERE IN THE ARCHIVE WHEN THE PROJECT BEGAN SEVERAL YEARS AGO. OUR CONCLUSIONS, PUBLISHED IN LANZ ET AL. (2013), DEMONSTRATE THE POWER OF THE TECHNIQUES TO TRACE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY ACROSS THE MERGER SEQUENCE. THE CONCLUSIONS, HOWEVER, WERE LIMITED BY THE SMALL NUMBERS. TODAY THE AVAILABLE DATASET IS MUCH LARGER AND, WITH THE END OF HERSCHEL, IS IN SOME SENSE COMPLETE. WE PROPOSE A FOCUSED EFFORT TO EXTEND OUR WORK TO THE LARGE SAMPLE DESCRIBED. THE MUCH LARGER SAMPLE WILL ENABLE US TO REACH MUCH FIRMER STATISTICAL CONCLUSIONS, AND TO ADDRESS THE PROCESSES IN INTERMEDIATE INTERACTION STAGES ACROSS A WIDER RANGE OF GALAXY MASS-RATIOS AND IMPACT PARAMETERS. OUR CATALOG OF ~23-BAND UV-FIR PHOTOMETRY ON THESE 180 (+25) GALAXIES WILL CONSTITUTE A LEGACY CONTRIBUTION. OUR CONCLUSIONS WILL HAVE APPLICATION FOR MERGERS IN THE MORE DISTANT UNIVERSE. OUR TEAM IS EXPERT IN THE IMPORTANT AND DIFFICULT ISSUES OF DATA REDUCTION AND ANALYSIS IN THE MANY BANDS REQUIRED FOR THIS PROJECT, IN MODELING AND USING BAYESIAN AND OTHER METHODS TO OBTAIN THE BEST FITS TO THE OBSERVATIONS FROM MULTI-COMPONENT GALAXY MODELS, IN THE SIMULATIONS, AND IN UNDERSTANDING PHYSICAL PROCESSES IN GALAXIES.
doc.MajorAgency: THE EVOLVING PHYSICAL PROCESSES IN INTERACTING GAL
doc.MajorFundingAgency: THE EVOLVING PHYSICAL PROCESSES IN INTERACTING GAL

doc.ContractDescription: SCIENCE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES THE OCCULTATION METHOD IS THE ONLY PRACTICAL TECHNIQUE FOR MEASURING THE SIZE DISTRIBUTION AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF SMALL SUBKM AND KM SIZED OBJECTS IN THE OUTER SOLAR SYSTEM OSS. MEASURING THESE PROPERTIES WILL PROVIDE UNIQUE INFORMATION ON BOTH THE DYNAMICAL PROCESSES WHICH SCULPTED THE OSS, AS WELL AS ON THE MATERIAL STRENGTH AND PROPERTIES OF ITS CONSTITUENT BODIES. WE HAVE INITIATED A GROUND-BASED SURVEY USING THE IMACS INSTRUMENT ON THE MAGELLAN BAADE TELESCOPE, SEARCHING FOR OCCULTATIONS OF BACKGROUND STARS BY SUB KM KUIPER BELT OBJECTS KBOS. OUR INITIAL RESULTS DEMONSTRATE THAT OUR SURVEY METHODOLOGY IS SOUND, AND THAT WE CAN SUCCESSFULLY DETECT SUB KM KBOS FROM THE GROUND. WE PROPOSE TO EXTEND OUR SURVEY FOR A FURTHER THREE YEARS SIX SEMESTERS, ALLOWING US TO COLLECT A MINIMUM OF 175,000 STAR HOURS OF HIGH CADENCE 40HZ AND HIGH SIGNAL TO NOISE PHOTOMETRY. THIS PROPOSED SURVEY WILL BE CONCENTRATED ON THE INTERSECTION OF THE GALACTIC PLANE AND THE PLANE OF THE ECLIPTIC IN THE DIRECTION OF THE GALACTIC CENTER, MAXIMIZING THE NUMBER OF POTENTIAL OCCULTATION EVENTS BETWEEN FOREGROUND KBOS AND BACKGROUND TARGET STARS. THE EXTENDED VERSION OF THE IMACS SURVEY THAT WE ARE PROPOSING WILL DISCOVER AN ORDER OF MAGNITUDE MORE OCCULTATIONS BY THESE SUBKM KBOS THAN HAS BEEN ACHIEVED TO DATE. THIS WILL PROVIDE THE FIRST EVER MEASUREMENT OF THE SIZE DISTRIBUTION OF SUB KM KBOS. THIS WILL BE OF HUGE SCIENTIFIC VALUE, AS A MEASUREMENT OF THE SLOPE OF THE SIZE DISTRIBUTION IN A COLLISIONAL POPULATION PROVIDES A DIRECT INSIGHT INTO THE MATERIAL PROPERTIES OF THE OBJECTS. OUR SURVEY RESULTS WILL THEREFORE PROVIDE THE FIRST INSIGHT INTO THE MECHANISMS SCULPTING THE FORMATION AND EVOLUTION OF THE COLLISIONAL KBO POPULATION. METHODOLOGY I DATA COLLECTION OBSERVATIONS WILL BE UNDERTAKEN USING THE IMACS INSTRUMENT ON THE MAGELLAN BAADE TELESCOPE, TO WHICH THE PROPOSAL TEAM HAS ACCESS VIA THREE INSTITUTIONAL TACS CFA AND MIT AND CARNEGIE. THE PROPOSAL TEAM HAS USED THIS FACILITY INSTRUMENT FOR OCCULTATION OBSERVATIONS ON MULTIPLE OCCASIONS AND ALL TEAM MEMBERS ARE EXPERIENCED, ABLE AND WILLING TO UNDERTAKE OBSERVATIONS. II DATA REDUCTION PI PAYNE HAS WRITTEN A PIPELINE SPECIFICALLY FOR THE REDUCTION OF IMACS OCCULTATION DATA. PI PAYNE WILL FURTHER OPTIMIZE THIS PIPELINE DURING THE COURSE OF THIS PROPOSED WORK, AND THEN UNDERTAKE TO REDUCE ALL DATA COLLECTED IN I. III DATA ANALYSIS ALL TEAM MEMBERS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE ANALYSIS OF THE DATA. THIS WILL INCLUDE THE INJECTION AND RECOVERY OF SYNTHETIC OCCULTATION EVENTS TO GAUGE SURVEY EFFICIENCY, THE SCRAMBLING OF DATA TO GAUGE THE RATE OF FALSE POSITIVES, AND THE DETAILED MODEL FITTING OF ALL RECOVERED OCCULTATION EVENTS. THE END RESULT OF THE ANALYSIS WILL BE PROVIDE A MEASUREMENT OF THE DENSITY OF OCCULTING OBJECTS IN THE OUTER SOLAR SYSTEM AS A FUNCTION OF OBJECT SIZE AND DISTANCE, ALLOWING THE FIRST EVER MEASUREMENT OF THE SIZE DISTRIBUTION OF SUB KM KBOS. RELEVANCE OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH TO THIS CALL C.6 SOLAR SYSTEM OBSERVATIONS THIS PROPOSAL HAS A PRIMARY ELEMENT OF NEW SOLAR SYSTEM OBSERVATION AND ITS AIM OF PERFORMING AN BROAD OCCULTATION SURVEY OF THE OUTER SOLAR SYSTEM CANNOT BE CARRIED OUT BY CURRENT SPACECRAFT MISSIONS INCLUDES SCIENTIFIC ANALYSIS AND PUBLICATION INVOLVES GROUND BASED ASTRONOMICAL OBSERVATIONS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE NATURE AND EVOLUTION OF THE SOLAR SYSTEM AND ITS INDIVIDUAL CONSTITUENTS AS THE PROPOSED OCCULTATION MEASUREMENTS WILL AFFORD AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE SIZE-DISTRIBUTION AND HENCE PHYSICAL PROPERTIES OF SUB KM OBJECTS IN THE OUTER SOLAR SYSTEM.
doc.MajorAgency: IMACS OCCULTATION SURVEY FOR SUB-KM KBOS
doc.MajorFundingAgency: IMACS OCCULTATION SURVEY FOR SUB-KM KBOS
